159.27: A spring belongs to the residents of the city, so if it comes to their lives against the lives of others, their lives come first, before the lives of others.
159.28: If they must choose between their own animals and the animals of others, their own animals come first, before the animals of others.
159.29: If they must choose between their own laundering and the laundering of others, their own laundering comes first, before the laundering of others
159.30: If, however, they must choose between the lives of others and their own laundering, the lives of others come first, before their own laundering.  However, Rabbi Yosei says
159.31: that their own laundering comes first, before the lives of others.

54.15: The law of the land is the law.

63.0: What does King David in Kohelet mean that A city is like a Man?

74.19: The Holy One, blessed be he, does not rest his divine presence except on a person who is might, wealthy, wise, and humble. And all of these [we learn] from Moses.

95.0: There was a man, who had a son who would steal bundles of flax. He [the man] took an oath that his son would not derive benefit from his [the man's] possessions.
95.11: But who told you that if he can't keep the scarf? [i.e. it is an effective transfer]
95.13: one takes possession of the scarf to give, but takes immediately [and gives possession immediately]! In this case, these assets, when will he take possession of them? By the time the grandson, the scholar, has taken possession, the scarf has returned to its owner [i.e. the act of transfer has long since ended].
95.2: And if your grandson will be a scholar, what shall happen then?
95.4: Then he should take possession [of the estate] to give it to his son.
95.7: He takes possession to give; and anyone to takes possession to give has not taken possession.
95.9: He has taken possession; for when one takes the scarf he has taken possession, and it is to give!

96.3: If he said 'Konam, I'll not taste anything that entered a pot', he may not eat anything cooked in a pot.
